title: 107_s1035
content: The Act may be cited as the "Great Lakes Preservation Act". Congress recognizes the Great Lakes as vital public resources crucial for the economies of the Great Lakes States, providing a significant portion of the world's fresh water supply and safe drinking water for millions. The Great Lakes Charter of 1985 serves as an international agreement for water diversion within the basin. The Great Lakes States and Provinces consult on water diversion decisions to protect the basin's resources. Governors manage day-to-day water decisions. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "Administrator" refers to the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency. "Bulk fresh water" is fresh water extracted for transportation without further processing. "From the Great Lakes basin" refers to water from specific lakes, interconnecting waterways, or tributaries. The term "Great Lake" refers to Lake Erie, Lake Huron, Lake Michigan, Lake Ontario, and Lake Superior. The term "Great Lakes Province" refers to Ontario or Quebec, Canada, while the term "Great Lakes State" refers to Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Minnesota, New York, Ohio, Pennsylvania, or Wisconsin. The term "Great Lakes State" includes Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Minnesota, New York, Ohio, Pennsylvania, or Wisconsin. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior, acting through the Director of the National Park Service. SEC. 4. MORATORIUM ON EXPORT OF BULK FRESH WATER. Bulk fresh water from the Great Lakes basin shall not be exported from the United States. This provision will end when a Congress-approved mechanism for water decisions is in place. The Federal Government should make an agreement with Canada to uphold the moratorium. SEC. 5. PRESERVATION OF HISTORIC GREAT LAKES LIGHTHOUSES. The Great Lakes have influenced settlement, commerce, and recreation. Lighthouses in the region are historically significant but are in poor condition. A study will be conducted to identify options for preserving them. The Secretary will conduct a study to identify options for preserving lighthouses in the Great Lakes States. This includes reviewing National Park Service programs and consulting with historical associations, preservation agencies, the Coast Guard, and other relevant entities. Authorization of appropriations is provided for this purpose. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the Secretary, the Commandant of the Coast Guard, and other relevant entities to carry out the study on preserving lighthouses in the Great Lakes States.
